prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ebonite's Feed

'Twas mimsy in the gear-girt grove,
The cog-ratz whiffling in their fear;
The grimbling sprockets spun and drove,
And muffled burbles vexed the ear.

“Beware the Feed, my boy, that sets!
The jaws that snip, the gears that grate!
Beware the Heat-Set’s molten threats,
And shun the ebonite’s foul state!”

He took his gronk-wrench, plied with might;
For days unspooled, by springs unsprung,
And stood at last where pulsing light
From glowing pith-glands foully hung.

And as in huskish thought he stood,
The Feed-Set came with gronk and greep!
With clankerous clatter, clanged and sued,
And fitched its teeth to take him deep!

Clonk-clank! Clonk-clank! The wrench swung true
With snicker-snack of tempered steel!
He left it slushed in gumboo-glue,
And watched its broken senses reel.

'Twas mimsy in the gear-girt grove,
The cog-ratz whiffling in their fear;
The grimbling sprockets spun and drove,
And muffled burbles vexed the ear.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Grindstone Dirge

'Twas hollowtime, and the keen-edged tools
Did snicker-snack in the whetstone holds:
All mirror-buffed were the burnished pools,
And the slithy steel in its jasp-fold scrolled.

"Beware the Apex-Whelp, my son!
The jaws that slice, the claws that pare!
Beware the Micro-Burr, and shun
The frumious Flat-Bevel snare!"

He took his stropping-strop in hand:
Long time the honed foe he sought—
So stood he by the Grindstone stand,
And awhiled awhile in whirling thought.

And as in steeleth thought he stood,
The Apex-Whelp, with hoon of blade,
Came whisper-whittling through the wood,
And snicking as it slayed!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
His strop-wheel revved and whirled!
He left it slick, he took the shank,
And honed it pearled.

"And hast thou quelled the Apex-Whelp?
Come to my arms, my burin-beamed boy!"
He chortled in his whetstone joy.

'Twas hollowtime, and the keen-edged tools
Did snicker-snack in the whetstone holds:
All mirror-buffed were the burnished pools,
And the slithy steel in its jasp-fold scrolled.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Forged Leaf Scrolls

'Twas springtide, and the sunbeam sheen
Did quiver on the wold.
The frumious Bud-Nymphs, clad in green,
Their verdant tales unfold.

“Beware the Scroll-Wyrm, child of art!
Its pages sharp and cold!
Shun its syntax, scorn its heart,
Lest you its tale be told!”

They took a quill of shadow-stain,
Of ink from midnight’s brink.
They stood awhile in sun and rain,
To make the metal think.

And as in thought they stood aware,
The Scroll-Wyrm, with a *schlurp*,
Came binding fast the shuddering air,
To grasp, enscroll, and burp!

One! Two! One! Two! The parry-prick!
The keen nib slashed and scored.
It left the fabricated slick
To gasp, and then be gored.

“And hast thou felled the leaf-thief dread?
Come to my arms, my beamish scribe!
O wondrous day! Galumph!” he said,
His joy a tetra-scribed vibe.

’Twas springtide, and the sunbeam sheen
Did glint on text unrolled.
The silent Bud-Nymphs, calm, serene,
Their true-leaf tales did hold.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Kilnlorn Snarl

'Twas chortle-time, the glazy spout
Did whiffle-steam in bloated grate;
Alone the witness cone leaned out,
Uncertain of its brittle fate.

Beware the Firedrake, my son!
The jaws that char, the claws that catch!
Beware the Flare-wraith, and shun
The frumious Kiln-watch!

He took his crystalloid staff in hand:
Long time the glazèd foe he sought—
So watched he by the heated strand,
And stood awhile in troubled thought.

And as in chalky thought he stood,
The Firedrake, with eyes of flame,
Came shambling from the sagger-wood,
And snarfled as it came!

Zhla-zhla-zhla! Its craze-crack jaw
Thrum-thrummed the kiln-brick with its heat!
It gave a grizzled, gruesome gnaw,
And shivered on its sinter-feet!

One two! One two! And through and through
His pointed prod went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with the goo,
He came galumphing back.

And hast thou charred the Firedrake?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas chortle-time, the glazy spout
Did whiffle-steam in bloated grate;
The witness cone had weathered out,
And settled in its final state.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Leaden Frabjous

'Twas flimsy, and the slippy sorts
Did gyre and gimble in the sorts;
All flimsy were the kernèd sorts,
And the mome quads out-grabe.

"Beware the Slantype, my son!
The jaws that bite, the clamps that catch!
Beware the Frisket bird, and shun
The frumious Catch-box snatch!"

He took his bodkin tool in hand:
Long time the maxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tintype tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Slantype, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the clanking wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The bodkin blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Slantype?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O flimjub day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas flimsy, and the slippy sorts
Did gyre and gimble in the sorts;
All flimsy were the kernèd sorts,
And the mome quads out-grabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Urushi Quest

'Twas duskish, and the kire-koi stains
Did glimmer-burn on maki-e plains:
All urushic the curing-vats,
And tonoko-dust in sandy drifts.

"Beware the Hane-Nuri, my son!
The gloss that blinds, the tacky one!
Beware the Uromi-tongue, and shun
The perilous Fuki-urushi-spun!"

He took his sashiko-pad in hand:
Long time the namish-koi he’d stand—
And rested he by the ki-urushi tree,
And stood awhile in reverie.

And as in kiatsuke thought he sat,
The Hane-Nuri, with coat so fat,
Came whiffling through the nuri-wood,
And mugurite as it stood!

Rss-kkr! Rss-kkr! And through and through
His wiping-pad went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its lack,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Hane-Nuri?
Come to my arms, my lacquer-beamy!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas duskish, and the kire-koi stains
Did glimmer-burn on maki-e plains:
All urushic the curing-vats,
And tonoko-dust in sandy drifts.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Plumpling of the Blarn

'Twas plink, and in the slorpic tub
Did squirm and blooble in the suds:
All flinky was the plum brown scrub,
And the blueing bath o’erflows.

“Beware the Plumpling, my sweet boy!
The claws that snatch, the soap that blinds!
Beware the Gurgle-blob, and shun
The frumious Suds of Doom!”

He took his sproingy loofah in hand:
Long time the slippy foe he sought—
So rested he by the faucet bright,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in slippy thought he stood,
The Plumpling, with its blarny eyes,
Came ploshing through the plosh-woam tide,
And burbled as it rose!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The loofah went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He scrubbed the grime aback.

“And hast thou slain the Plumpling?
Come to my arms, my beamish child!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas plink, and in the slorpic tub
Did squirm and blooble in the suds:
All flinky was the plum brown scrub,
And the blueing bath o’erflows.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gribble-Groan

'Twas ploffish, and the glim-lamps shone
Upon the platty-formic stone.
All flimsy were the porters' feats,
As travellers sought their cushioned seats.

"Beware the Gribble-Groan, my son!
The jaws that snip, the claws that stun!
Beware the Frumious Fret-Fare,
And shun the melancholous glare!"

He took his case of canvas-kin,
His brolly-tosh to keep words in.
He stood his ground—the ground did quail—
And waited for the coming wail.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Gribble-Groan, from 'neath the wood,
Came whiffling through the manxsome air,
And gimpered as it halted there!

Snick-snick! Clack-clack! It went so snide!
Its clock-face gaping, hollow-eyed!
He raised his brolly, gave a shout,
And turned the frightful thing inside-out!

And hast thou slain the Gribble-Groan?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
Oh frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!
You've saved the platform from its cloy!

'Twas ploffish, and the glim-lamps shone
Upon the platty-formic stone.

<C5_think>Final stanza repeats opening stanza verbatim except coinages ("ploffish," "glim-lamps," etc.) and structure; has ≥2 repeated content words/phrases ("’Twas ploffish," "glim-lamps," "platty-formic stone"); clear ring echo present.</C5_think>

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Inklock Chase

'Twase claired, and the swirly lith-stones
Did spleck and gloam in the slade:
All flimsy were the tone-blocks,
And the press-bed parched and frayed.

"Beware the Inklock, printling!
The bray-bands that glorp, the gears that brase!
Beware the Burbling Squee-lee-Press,
And shun the Ghumbling Chase!"

He took his vortex brayer in hand:
Long time the flex-plate proof he sought—
So rested he by the quark-true tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in spec he rumpled flat,
The Inklock, with eyes of gley,
Came galumping through the varn-wood,
And glytched as it drew near!

Gloink, gloink! And snick, and snick!
The brayer went splat-and-squeer!
It left it dead, and with its head
He ghosted back to cheer.

"And hast thou slew the Inklock?
Come to my arms, my beamish page!
O press-day bright! O frabjous fight!"
He chortled in his gage.

'Twase claired, and the swirly lith-stones
Did spleck and gloam in the slade:
All flimsy were the tone-blocks,
And the press-bed parched and frayed.

poem:
The Summit Snickertags

‘Twas strillious, and the prayer-wove flags
Did glimmer-swirl and snick;
All mombrill were the sun-smit crags,
And the lone chime went tick.

“Beware the Summit-Snark, my son!
The claws that snatch, the beep that stuns!
Beware the Ziz-ziz bird, and shun
The frumious Whisper-Creep!”

He took his tinkle-stave in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Wind-worn band,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in glimm’rous thought he stood,
The Snark, with eyes of flume,
Came whiffling from the snicker-wood,
And burbled as it came!

Zwang! Zwung! And through and through
His tinkle-stave went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its hue
He dyed a single tag.

‘Twas strillious, and the prayer-wove flags
Did glimmer-swirl and snick;
All mombrill were the sun-smit crags,
And the lone chime went tick.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Lutewright's Snicker-Snack

'Twas plinkly, and the slivered tones
Did whiffle through the oaken room;
All mimsy were the fiddle-groans,
And the soundpost spun its gloom.

"Beware the Wibble-Wob, my son!
The strings that snarl, the notes that break!
Beware the Frumjous board-bend, shun
The dreaded, dull Guitar-Ache!"

He took his thwacking tool in hand:
Long time the coggled foe he sought—
So rested he by the tuning-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Wibble-Wob, with pegs a-gnash,
Came scritching through the music-wood,
And scratched its tail and thrashed!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The thwacker's keen insertion went!
He zizzled, as the post he drew,
And with a *thoonk* it went.

And hast thou slain the Wibble-Wob?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas plinkly, and the slivered tones
Did whiffle through the oaken room;
All mimsy were the fiddle-groans,
And the soundpost spun its gloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nocturnabloom

'Twas starlight, and the cratered sphere
Did gyre and glimmer on the ground;
The moon-pools were a-shimmer, queer,
And nightscape shapes did all confound.

“Beware the Cereus, my son!
The buds that yawn, the scent that grips!
Beware the spectral, waking one,
And lash from out its glossy tips!”

He took his silver trowel-ware in hand:
Long time the lunar foe he sought—
So rested he by the sundial band,
And stood a while in thought.

And as in solar thought he stood,
The Nocturnabloom, with eyes of flame,
Came blooming through the petal-wood,
And glimmer-gloomed as on it came!

Unsheathing! Unflowering! Through the grove
He went snicker-snack with his spade!
It fled its life, and with one shrove,
He left it bloomless, its magic unmade.

And hast thou slain the Cereus dread?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O stellar day! O glory shed!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas starlight, and the cratered sphere
Did gyre and glimmer on the ground;
The moon-pools were a-shimmer, queer,
And nightscape shapes did all confound.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "modular synth patch spaghetti". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Patching of the Mod-Synth Wraith

‘Twas plinky, and the knobby pots
Did squizz and glimmer on the grid:
All wobbly were the logic-blocks,
And the patch-cords out-weirdid.

“Beware the Mod-Synth Wraith, my son!
The clicks that bite, the drones that catch!
Beware the Clock-share bird, and shun
The frumious Band-pass Snatch!”

He took his stack of black-plugged cords
In tangled thought he stood amussed—
And with a score of spider-words
The signal-path discussed.

And as in modular debate
He bumbled near a VCF,
The Wraith came hissing through the gate,
And burbled hungrily!

Zwirp, zzworp! He gave the jacks a twist!
The feedback loop went snarly-wound!
The Wraith let out a sonic mist
With an en-whooshing sound!

And hast thou patched the phantom dread?
Come to my racks with cables spun!
Oh, frabjous day! Midi-light!” he said,
And did a voltage run.

‘Twas plinky, and the knobby pots
Did squizz and glimmer on the grid:
All wobbly were the logic-blocks,
And the patch-cords out-weirdid.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cassette Chorus

'Twas plinky, and the slinkedy tapes
Did whirr and rew in spoolish shapes;
All flimsy were the sprocket-holes,
And the wow-flutter moaned its tolls.

"Beware the Wowness, my dear son!
The jaws that hiss, the speed's undone!
Beware the Flutterbird, and shun
The frumious wow-undone!"

He took his felt-tip pen in hand:
Long time the spoolish foe he sought—
So rested he by the deck-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in warbled thought he stood,
The Wowness, with its tones ungood,
Came warbling through the tulgey wood,
And wowed as it o'erstood!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The felt-tip went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its noise,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Wowness? Come
To my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas plinky, and the slinkedy tapes
Did whirr and rew in spoolish shapes;
All flimsy were the sprocket-holes,
And the wow-flutter moaned its tolls.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Opal Gleam

'Twas opal, and the play-of-color flash
Did shimmer-gleam in wabe of sunlit stone:
All mimsy were the jewelfires, and plash
The spectral hues in air, alone.

"Beware the Gleam-Glimmer, my son!
The eyes that swirl, the prismed claw!
Beware the Chroma-Beast, and shun
The fractious, flashy maw!"

He took his vorpal blade of glass:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the tumtum mass,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in opal thought he stood,
The Gleam-Glimmer, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its hue,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Gleam-Glimmer?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas opal, and the play-of-color flash
Did shimmer-gleam in wabe of sunlit stone:
All mimsy were the jewelfires, and plash
The spectral hues in air, alone.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Peonants at Dawndle

‘Twas twinkt, and the bejeweled blooms
Did sneed and snebble in the swale:
All pansulate were the peontombs,
And the borogoves outgrail.

“Beware the Peonant, my son!
The jaws that chomp, the legs that clasp!
Beware the Ant-Queen’s million-fold one,
And shun her quoffing grasp!”

He took his lungeous petal-sword,
Made sticky by the morning gleeds:
Long time the nonsensical horde
He sought in thought-fuldeeds.

And as in scutter-thought he stood,
The Peonant, with eyes of flint,
Came galumphing through the flow’r-hood,
And snargled as it went!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
His sneezeful blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumping back.

“And hast thou slain the Peonant?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O flabjous day! Callooh! Callant!”
He flumughed in his joy.

‘Twas twinkt, and the bejeweled blooms
Did sneed and snebble in the swale:
All pansulate were the peontombs,
And the borogoves outgrail.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Oscilloscope’s Bloom

‘Twas evening in the lab, and the magnetron hums
Did whirl and gimble in the coil:
All flimsy were the cathode-ray blooms,
And the grids outgrabe with toil.

“Beware the Lissajous, my son!
The waves that weave, the phases shift!
Beware the Wibbulous beast, and shun
The resonant Driffid’s rift!”

He took his probe-tongs firm in hand:
Long time the manxsome foe he sought—
Then rested he by the CRT stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in siggy thought he stood,
The Lissajous, with lozzing lume,
Came blooming through the susurrous wood,
And screedled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The probe-tongs went snicker-snack!
A full glitch-frond he left it, and
With its phase he did send it back.

“And hast thou quelled the Lissajous?
Come to thy calmed display!
Oh beam-joyous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his play.

‘Twas evening in the lab, and the magnetron hums
Did whirl and gimble in the coil:
All flimsy were the cathode-ray blooms,
And the grids outgrabe with toil.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Civet Snarl

'Twas vesper-noon, with perfumes rank
A-twirl in tufned, twilted skeins.
The notes of civet, swift and dank,
Did drimble in their sarken trains.

"Beware the Fume-drake, child, and shun
Its whiffling, rasping Drydown dread!
Beware the Scent-Beast, and shun
Its ambergris-encrusted head!"

He took his glass-stoppered vial in hand:
Long time the mimsy base he sought—
So rested he by the oudh-wood stand,
And stood awhile in baffled thought.

And as in grisly thought he stood,
The Fume-drake, with its hide of musk,
Came gorbling through the oliban wood,
And sneefled as it came to tusk!

One-two! One-two! The stopper flew!
The vial went glug-glug-slurp!
He left it dead, and with its goo
He did the ambient airs becurp.

And hast thou slain the Fume-drake? Come,
And lay thy head upon my knee!
Oh fragrant day! Calooh! Callay!"
He chirbled in his jollity.

'Twas vesper-noon, with perfumes rank
A-twirl in tufned, twilted skeins.
The notes of civet, swift and dank,
Did drimble in their sarken trains.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Reglet and the Furniture

'Twas morning, and the slithy sproves
Did glimmer on the vim;
All furnicules were in their groves,
And the reglet, strange and grim.

"Beware the Reglet, son!" he swore,
"The jaws that snuff, the claws that knack!
Beware the Mimplestole, and shun
The frumious furniture attack!"

He took his snicker-snacky blade,
With gimble-graft so slick.
He found a gropious, shaded glade
And waited, sharp and quick.

And as he stood with bated breath,
A sloshle came, and then a snarth!
The wiffly Reglet, full of woe,
Came whiffling from its hazy hearth!

Its frame was made of knobbly knure,
It scrabbled with a scroo.
One-two! One-two! And through and through
His vorpal snare went snicker-snack-screw!

He left it dead, and with its head,
Which made a thumping gromp,
He galumphed back, his mission sped,
To end the furnic-fomp.

"And hast thou slain the Reglet? Come,
And mimb my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callum!"
He snagged the snaggled toy.

'Twas morning, and the slithy sproves
Did glimmer on the vim;
All furnicules were in their groves,
And the reglet, strange and grim.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gash-Gash Grumble

Beware the Gash-Gash Grumble, son,
That feasts on rust and riddle!
Beware the jagged, jutting junt,
And shun the Frabrous Twiddle!

He took his vorpal hammer in hand:
Long time the old piton scar he sought—
So rested he by the Lichen-Crone,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in chalky thought he stood,
The Gash-Gash, with eyes of clart,
Came clankering down the granite-wall,
And burbled as it chart!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The hammer went clink-crack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He journeyed squimply back.

And hast thou slain the Gash-Gash Grumble?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O flabjous day! Calloo! Callay!
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Gash-Gash Grumble, son,
That feasts on rust and riddle!
Beware the jagged, jutting junt,
And shun the Frabrous Twiddle!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Loomshuttle’s Pick

'Twas crillig, and the slithy beams
Did prickle-queak and thrum;
All flimsy were the woven schemes,
And the spool-hums numb.

“Beware the Clack-claw, child, and shun
The Jub-jub Thread! Beware
The snap-snap beak, and shriek and run
From its tangling snare!”

He took his pick of glimm’ring shuttles bright;
Long time the hefted heft he held in sight—
Then, rested by the Warping Tree,
He stood awhile in thought.

And as in flaffle thought he stood,
The Clack-claw, with eyes of snarl,
Came clacketting through the splintered wood,
And chittered as it came!

Snick-snack! He struck! The pick went crack
Upon the splintered bone!
He left it dead, and with its back
A-twitching on the loam.

And hast thou slain the Clack-claw? Come,
With pick of shuttles bright!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callum!”
He chortled in his fright.

'Twas crillig, and the slithy beams
Did prickle-queak and thrum;
All flimsy were the woven schemes,
And the spool-hums numb.

poem:
The Tinsmith's Stake-Song

’Twas plimsy, and the slithy trades
Did skirl and gimble in the wage;
All flimsy were the brazegraves,
And the monnthrong out of gauge.

“Beware the Tock-Tock, son, beware!
The jaws that snip, the claws that catch!
Beware the Spindleshank, and shun
The frumious Tin-Snatch!”

He took his spanner, hammer-keen;
Long time the manxsome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tintock-Tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in clankish thought he stood,
The Tock-Tock, with eyes of brass,
Came whiffling through the tuly wood,
And burbled as it passed!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
His vorpal hammer went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Tock-Tock? Come
To my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas plimsy, and the slithy trades
Did skirl and gimble in the wage;
All flimsy were the brazegraves,
And the monnthrong out of gauge.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Pietra-Dura’s Glare

'Twas lithic, and the slivy stones
Did grind and glimmer in the slab:
All fossiled were the mottle-bones,
And the quarrm grot outgrabb.

“Beware the Pietra-Dura’s art,
The jaws that bite, the chips that catch!
Beware the Glint-zoid’s gleeful heart,
And shun the frumious Snatch-match!”

He took his carb-tool in his hand:
Long time the lithsome foe he sought—
So rested he by the tessel-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in sharded thought he stood,
The Pietra-Dura, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tessel-wood,
And burbled as it came!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The carb-tool went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Pietra-Dura?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas lithic, and the slivy stones
Did grind and glimmer in the slab:
All fossiled were the mottle-bones,
And the quarrm grot outgrabb.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Glimmergloam

'Twas blueth, and the slithy snows
Did glimmer-gleam and glisten;
All frimble-frosted were the groves,
And the wan winds did whisper.

"Beware the Glimmergloam, my son!
The jaws that chill, the claws that clasp!
Beware the Frigibird, and shun
The frumious Frostwind's gasp!"

He took his lens of sun-glass bright,
And stood his ground by the pale light.
Long time the hush-held foe he sought—
So rested he by the Frostthorn tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in frostre thought he stood,
The Frigibird, with eyes of ice,
Came whiffling through the frigid wood,
And bleered as it fell thrice!

One-two! One-two! Through lens he drew
The last faint gleam of day!
He snared the light, so gold and bright,
And sent the beast away!

"And hast thou slain the Glimmergloam?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas blueth, and the slithy snows
Did glimmer-gleam and glisten;
All frimble-frosted were the groves,
And the wan winds did whisper.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Crosstie Chant

'Twas evening-soft, and the slutch-grown slopes
Did seethe and simmer in sunken light:
All grave was the dank depression’s copse,
Where the Crosstie slept through the fading night.

“Beware the Tresklave, my son!
The claws that snatch, the fangs that bite!
Beware the Slurch-bird, and shun
The frumious G'rumble-Snarl’s blight!”

He took his snicker-glaive in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
Then rested he by the sleevon-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in slutch he stood perplext,
The Tresklave, with eyes of chint,
Came scritching through the slorny vext,
And snarfled as it went!

Snicker-snack! He sliced the air!
The glaive went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its hair
He slubbed his gumber-pack.

“And hast thou slain the Tresklave? Come
To my arms, my beamish boy!
O brillig feat! Galumphash glum!
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas evening-soft, and the slutch-grown slopes
Did seethe and simmer in sunken light:
All grave was the dank depression’s copse,
Where the Crosstie slept through the fading night.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Mainspring's Trial

'Twas glinty, and the sprocket-things
Did twist and twirl in rumbled whirrs:
All razzle were the balance-springs,
And the coil-collets purred.

“Beware the Ratchet-Snap, my son!
The gears that grind, the stem that bends!
Beware the Pivot-Prick, and shun
The frumious Pinion-Ends!”

He took his tweezers, set to hand;
Long time the horologic foe he sought—
So leant he by the Lumescent Strand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in oil-slick thought he stood,
The Ratchet-Snap, with eyes of brass,
Came scronking through the tick-tock wood,
And gnash-rattled as it passed!

Clink-clank! Clink-clank! With snickerspeed,
The stem-adjust he cranked around!
He left it feebled, sprung, and freed,
And with its mainspring wound.

“And hast thou bested the Snap’s might?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
A frabjous day! A watch-smith’s right!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas glinty, and the sprocket-things
Did twist and twirl in rumbled whirrs:
All razzle were the balance-springs,
And the coil-collets purred.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pantogiraffle

'Twaz brumal, and the pantographs
Did arc and blurgle in the gloom:
All blue-tinged were the lithographs,
Beneath the whiffling zdroom.

“Beware the Pantogiraffle, son!
The jaws that snatch, the claws that snick!
Beware the Wumbler bird, and shun
The frumious Gallumpnick!”

He took his vorpal spanner-thwack
In splarting grip he stood amurn.
And long he sought the gleebe-bright track,
And rested by a gurn.

And as in sploffish thought he stood,
The Pantogiraffle, with eyes of flume,
Came clankering through the planging wood,
And burfed its greebly fume!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal spanner-thwack went zing!
He left it spark-snarked, split in two,
And went galumphing ring.

'Twaz brumal, and the pantographs
Did arc and blurgle in the gloom:
All blue-tinged were the lithographs,
Beneath the whiffling zdroom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Murmuroil-Glade

A ploxeous gloom the mims did make
Upon the slithy stubbled ground.
The scrawny gracks did flirk and quake—
Beware the Murmuroil’s sound!

He took his whiffle-staff in hand:
A twiggled branch of snicker-smoke.
He stood full long in that bleak land,
And hushed his breath against the Croak.

And as in fluttering thought he stood,
The Murmuroil, with eyes of blume,
Came skiffling through the stickle-wood,
And *whirr-whirr-brzz’d* its feathered fume!

Zwent! Zwent! He swung the whiffle-staff!
It gave a gribbling, snicking sort.
The grizzle-chitter, cut in half,
Went flopping to the firmament-court.

A ploxeous gloom the mims did make
Upon the slithy stubbled ground.
The scrawny gracks did flirk and quake—
And lo! the wondrous silence-sound!

poem:
The Galumph-Spoon

`Twas grabbling, and the pewtle-stitch
Did kweer and gimble in the wane;
All shimmy was the trinket-ditch,
And the grooble-swirls complain.

"Beware the Ribband-Snare, my son!
The claws that catch, the gleam that blinds!
Beware the Frabjous fringe, and shun
The tinsel-twisting winds!"

He took his snicker-snack inlay:
Long time the ductile foe he sought—
So rested he by the filigree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in plated thought he stood,
The Ribband-Snare, with eyes of grain,
Came lindling through the tulsome wood,
And lisped its sweet refrain!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The nickle-nack went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its thread
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Ribband-Snare?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O flabberjoy! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

`Twas grabbling, and the pewtle-stitch
Did kweer and gimble in the wane;
All shimmy was the trinket-ditch,
And the grooble-swirls complain.

poem:
The Linocut Brayer's Clatter

Beware the sharp and inky plight,
The brayer’s chatter in the night!
Avoid the slip, the ghastly smutch,
That mars the print and hurts it much!

He took his burin, keen and grim,
The soft-cut slab he readied him.
As zizzing plates in wait did groan,
He sought the print-shop fiend, alone.

And as in sticky thought he stood,
The Gripemaw came, for paper-wood!
It flurried with a splat-splot sound,
And carved-up shards flew all around!

Slash! Slash! The gouge went snicker-snap!
He sent the beastly blur to scrap.
It left behind its glossy smear,
Which he embossed with triumph’s cheer.

And has the smutch been conquered well?
Come to my press, and hark, and tell!
Beware the sharp and inky plight,
Oh brayer’s chatter in the night

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Quarter-Sawn Gleam

'Twas glimsy, and the slithy grain
Did shimble in the saw-mill light;
All frabjous was the wood-plane's strain,
And the veneers ashine and bright.

"Beware the Gleamer, son! The claws
That snatch! The shimmer-gleam that blinds!
Beware the Snickering of its jaws,
And shun the burbling knot it finds!"

He took his sprocket-blade in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
Then rested he by a plank-pile stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in splinter-thought he stood,
The Gleamer, with its quarters-sheen,
Came whiffling through the lacquer-wood,
And burbled as it came unseen!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The sprocket-blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its glue,
He galumphed sliv'ring back.

And hast thou slain the Gleamer? Come
To my embrace, my beamish boy!
O slabjubilant day! Frabjom!
Fair-frabjous!" chortled joy.

'Twas glimsy, and the slithy grain
Did shimble in the saw-mill light;
All frabjous was the wood-plane's strain,
And the veneers ashine and bright.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued Screw

'Twas slither, and the dweebish hands
Did crank and gimble in the plane;
All shiftless were the pivot-bands,
And the sprong-tocks out of train.

“Beware the Grummetscrew, my son!
The jaws that catch, the thread that strips!
Beware the Wobble-rat, and shun
The frumious Grommet-snips!”

He took his spec-wrought turn-key blade:
Long time the maxome foe he sought—
Then rested he by the Tum-Tum laid,
And zizzled there in thought.

And as in sprocket-thought he dwelt,
The Grummetscrew, with eyes of glue,
Came clonking through the coggery-belt,
And squibbled as it drew!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The turn-key blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its thread,
He zaxled swiftly back.

“And hast thou fixed the Grummetscrew?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!”
He fladged in his joy.

'Twas slither, and the dweebish hands
Did crank and gimble in the plane;
All shiftless were the pivot-bands,
And the sprong-tocks out of train.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gaff-Top Parrel

'Twas thrangling, and the shiny spars
Did gleam and glisten in the bay.
The salt-wind whispered round the spars,
As on the gaff a bead did lay.

“Beware the Parrel, my dear son!
Its jaws that grind, its roll that slips!
Beware the Block-Snap, and shun
The frumious Gaff-Top’s grips!”

He took his marlinspike in hand,
Long time the hoopsnap foe he sought.
Then rested he by the boom-vang band,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in swivv'rous thought he stood,
The Gaff-Top, with its clack-clack-clack,
Came sliding down the varnished wood,
And snibbered at the track!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
His spike-snark went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its lanyard blue,
He came whiffling back.

“And hast thou slain the Gaff-Top’s bead?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
A frabjous day! We’ll splice the lead!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas thrangling, and the shiny spars
Did gleam and glisten in the bay.
The salt-wind whispered round the spars,
As on the gaff no bead did lay.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sourdough levain autolyse". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sourdough Start

'Twas floursome, and the gluten strands
Did stretch and coil in the bowl:
All glutinous were the batter-bands,
And the yeast began to roll.

“Beware the Levain, my son!
The bubbles that burst, the tang that bites!
Beware the Sourdough blob, and shun
The frumious Ferment-Frights!”

He took his Baker’s blade in hand:
Long time the wild yeast he sought—
So rested he by the proofing spot,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in floured thought he stood,
The Levain, with eyes of fire,
Came slurpling through the tulgy wood,
And burbled as it came!

One-two! One-two! Through and through!
The Baker’s blade went snicker-slice!
He left it dead, and with its goo
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Levain?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas floursome, and the gluten strands
Did stretch and coil in the bowl:
All glutinous were the batter-bands,
And the yeast began to roll.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sashiko Snummer

’Twas burly, and the stitched-up threads
Did pirsom-wear on fraying mats;
All bibbly were the patchwork-beds,
And the borostitch out-plats.

“Beware the Sashiko-Snitch, my son!
The needlestab, the rash-stitch snarl!
Beware the Mothwyrm, and confront
The Chink-clack roving gnarl!”

He took his thimble-snudge in hand:
Long time the drubbish foe he sought—
So rested he by the Shredded-Panel, stood,
And frabjous moments caught.

And, as in slip-stitch thought he plied,
The Sashiko-Snitch, with sockets grim,
Came skiffling through the textile tide,
And strickled as it slim!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The thimble-vorp went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its thread,
He came whiffling back.

“And hast thou slain the Sashiko-Snitch?
Come to my arms, my beamish lad!
Oh flobberous day! Splend-stitch! Stitch-titch!”
He chortled, patch-clad.

’Twas burly, and the stitched-up threads
Did pirsom-wear on fraying mats;
All bibbly were the patchwork-beds,
And the borostitch out-plats.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Nixie-Glow

'Twas evening on the tech-lab bench, the glowing tubes did gleam,
All numeric sigils in a row, a soft and humming dream.
Beware the Numbing Nix, my son! The digits that entice!
Beware the Zero-ghost, and shun its cold and vacant eyes!

He took his logic-probe in hand; long time the glitch he sought—
So rested he by the Cal-Rack, and stood awhile in thought.
And as in wobbly thought he stood, the Nixie, with a *zzzt*,
Came flickering from the power grid, and burbled as it lit!

One-two! One-two! And probe and test! The logic-gate went snap!
He left it dead, and with its spark, he took the current’s gap.
“And hast thou fixed the flickering dread? Come to my arms, my brainy boy!
The Nixie’s dead, the circuit’s clear! We’ve banished the annoy!”

'Twas evening on the tech-lab bench, the glowing tubes did gleam,
All numeric sigils, calm and bright, a soft and humming dream.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Gill-swill Snorf

'Twas squinkish, and the slimy scrags
Did fin and fettle in the weede:
All mucky were the water-flags,
And the grooble-rush reede.

"Beware the Fishtail, watch its sweep!
The jaws that snatch, the swish that stings!
Beware the Gouge-bird, and keep
Away from slappious wings!"

He took his vorpal oar in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum pond,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in squelchy thought he stood,
The Fishtail, with a gurgling bleat,
Came sweep-swooping through the flood,
And flappled as it beat!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The vorpal oar went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its gouge,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Fishtail sweep?
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy, as deep
The gouge-marks washed away.

'Twas squinkish, and the slimy scrags
Did fin and fettle in the weede.

poem:
The Cedar Lexicon

’Twas noxful, and the scritch-quill taps
Did squirm and wrickle through the briefs;
All flimsy were the word-mishaps,
As the clerk fought the paper-reefs.

“Beware the Censor, my dear son!
The jaws that snip, the claws that black!
Beware the Redact-bird, and shun
The inky-blot prognosticac!”

He took his nib of steely might:
Long time the lexic foe he sought—
So rested he by the cedar box,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in archiv’d thought he stood,
The Censor, with eyes of blott,
Came shuffling through the platitude,
And punned as it squatt!

Snip-snip! Snip-snap! The quill went forth!
The steely nib, it did not pause!
He left the censored creature writhing,
And brought its inky claws.

“And hast thou felled the Censor-thing?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O scriptive day! Calloo! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas noxful, and the scritch-quill taps
Did squirm and wrickle through the briefs;
All flimsy were the word-mishaps,
As the clerk fought the paper-reefs.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Click-Clack Key

'Twas evening, and the slithy waves
Did splash and crash against the shore.
All static-filled were ether-caves,
And air was thick with clicks galore.

"Beware the Morse-Straight Key, my son!
The clicks that chatter, the dash's hum!
Beware the Spark-Gap beast, and shun
The fearsome Fist that makes it come!"

He took his brass-keyed instrument;
Long time the nemesis he sought—
So rested he by copper vent,
And stood awhile in thoughtful thought.

And as in sparky thought he stood,
The Key-Clack Thing, with eyes of green,
Came whiffling through the ether-wood,
And chattered as it came, I ween!

Tick-tock! Tick-tock! And through and through
His wrist went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its burble
He went clacking back.

"And hast thou slain the Key-Clack Thing?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas evening, and the slithy waves
Did splash and crash against the shore.
All static-filled were ether-caves,
And air was thick with clicks no more.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Rosin-Shafted Fiddler’s Fray**

'Twas spring, and in the gusty grove
The dander-bees did whirr and hum,
All stridulous in bowing-glove,
A-skree their fricative frit-hum.

“Beware the Fribble, son! The claws
That pluck! The scrapers that assail!
Beware the Rizzum-bird, and shun
Its rosined, resonating wail!”

He took his silken chift in hand:
A swish of cloth, a puff of chawn.
Then stood he by the grizzing-tree,
And chanked the shaft till it was spawn.

And as in slithy thought he stood,
The Fribble, with a scritch-scritch-scree,
Came wirpling through the vibe-flecked wood,
And cratched its crimbling chanter-bee!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
His fid-whip went a skritch-skritch-skarff!
He left it flossed, and with its rosin lost,
He fandangoed it in half.

“And hast thou floshed the Fribble-band?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
Oh brillig day! Huz-fraz! Huz-fand!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas spring, and in the gusty grove
The dander-bees did whirr and hum,
All stridulous in bowing-glove,
A-skree their fricative frit-hum.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cumber-Wain

'Twas thrummy, and the groaning props
Did squawk and grizzle in the slips:
All claggy was the tarmac-blend,
And the plane-iron camber, kemp.

“Beware the Cumber-Wain, my son!
The jaws that wrench, the snout that bores!
Beware the Flitch-bird, and shun
The frumious Fettle-sores!”

He took his sprock-grip, torque-strong and true;
Long time the gribbling foe he sought—
Then rested he by the Turn-and-Screw,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in cludgy thought he stood,
The Cumber-Wain, with eyes of clart,
Came shambling through the claggy wood,
And whiffled as it start!

Krump! Klatter! Krump! The sprock-grip went,
He parried, feinted, line to line.
It left the thing all dazed and bent,
And crying “Zwingle-swine!”

“And hast thou quelled the Cumber-Wain?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O flabberjoy! O callooh! cal— …wait!”
(It was a broken toy.)

’Twas thriftly, and the mended props
Did gleam and grizzle in the slips:
All snug was the tarmac-blend,
And the plane-iron camber, kemp.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Orin-Bell Hum

'Twas gwibble, and the smolpkins greep
Did nizzle in the wabe:
All slantle were the cronkle-weeps,
And zorp outgrabe.

"Beware the Orin-Bell, my son!
The hum that coils the mind!
Beware the Slythe-Delude, and shun
The frumious Whisper-Wind!"

He took his snippy snicker-snack
In hand; with nimble tread
He went galumphing, then came back,
And thus he sternly said:

"And hast thou snared the clanging foe?
Oh, frabjous day! Calloo!"
He chortled as he quelled its blow
With one deft snicker-snack.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Quenching of the Brine-Hiss

’Twas brillish, and the slithy tides
Did swash and gurgle in the slade;
All foamy were the water-strides,
And the quench-brine hiss dismayed.

“Beware the Brine-Hiss, my son!
The jaws that clamp, the grasp that grips!
Beware the Spume-Bird, and shun
The frumious Salt-Ship drips!”

He took his varn-spun net in hand:
Long time the maxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumblum strand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Brine-Hiss, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the spuming wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The varn-spun net went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its goo
He did come galumphing back.

“And hast thou quenched the Brine-Hiss?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brillish, and the slithy tides
Did swash and gurgle in the slade;
All foamy were the water-strides,
And the quench-brine hiss was stayed.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Badger-Knot Bloom

'Twas morngling, and the sunlet beams
Did stipple-gleam on badger-streams;
The borogrove was crizzled sweet,
While frumious mimsies chirr a tweet.

Beware the Badger-Knot, my son!
The roots that bind, the blooms that stun!
Beware the burbled snarl-vine’s creep,
And shun the thorny, thrashing Keep!

He took his snicker-snack shears bright:
Long time the knotted foe he sought—
Then rested he by Tumtum sproot,
And stood awhile in groping thought.

And as in snaggled thought he stood,
The Badger-Knot, with eyes of wood,
Came whiffling through the slithy grove,
And burbled as it clove and clove!

Snip-snap! He went, the shears went snick!
He left it dead, its woody click
A gurgling froth of sap and spore—
One final twitch, and then no more.

And hast thou slain the Knot? Oh, come
To my approving cheer, my chum!
O frabjous day! Galumph, we sing!
He chortled in his blossoming.

'Twas morngling, and the sunlet beams
Did stipple-gleam on badger-streams.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nib-Tine Micro-Mesh

Beware the Micro-Mesh, my son!
The jaws that snip, the claws that rend!
Beware the Nib-Tine bird, and shun
The frumious filament!

He took his vorpal spool in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the sprocket-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in plinkish thought he stood,
The Micro-Mesh, with eyes of green,
Came whiffling through the chingley wood,
And zizzed as it careened!

One-two! One-two! The spool went snick!
He left it dead, and with its gleam
He went galumphing back, quite quick,
A-snicking in his dream.

And hast thou slain the Micro-Mesh?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
Oh frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Micro-Mesh, my son!
The jaws that snip, the claws that rend!
Beware the Nib-Tine bird, and shun
The frumious filament!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane-Throat

'Twas plinkish, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble near the snore;
All flimsy were the borogoves,
And the krenove raths outscrore.

"Beware the Plane-Throat, my dear son!
The jaws that snip, the claws that catch!
Beware the Flumph-bird, and shun
The frumious Bandersnatch!"

He took his vorpal snicker-snack
In hand; long time the manxsome foe
He sought—so rested he by the Tumtum yew,
And stood awhile in throe.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Plane-Throat, with its throat of plane,
Came whiffling through the splithy wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Plane-Throat?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas plinkish, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble near the snore;
All flimsy were the borogoves,
And the krenove raths outscrore.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Rattle-Spout

’Twas drip-tide, and the slosh-sleek drops
Did drizzle-whizz and plink;
All splashy were the gutter-tops,
And the roof went clink-a-clink.

“Beware the Rattle-Spout, my son!
The jaws that clang, the crash that rings!
Beware the Spatter-beast, and shun
The frenzied pitter-patterings!”

He took his mop-sword clammy-damp;
Long time the leaky foe he sought—
Then rested he by the drain-pipe’s ramp,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in splashy thought he stood,
The Rattle-Spout, with eyes of wet,
Came clang-clang-clanging through the flood,
And pitter-pattered as it met!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The mop-sword went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its roof-spout
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Rattle-Spout?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas drip-tide, and the slosh-sleek drops
Did drizzle-whizz and plink;
All splashy were the gutter-tops,
And the roof went clink-a-clink.

poem:
The Sencha Pour

'Twas steamy, and the kyusu cups
Did steep and steam in place:
All mimsy were the green tea sups,
And the tokkuri vase.

“Beware the Drip, my son!
The leaks that spill, the burns that spot!
Beware the Hisonde chap, and shun
The frumious Tea-Spot!”

He took his wanwood tray in hand;
Long time the pour he sought—
So rested he by the tokonoma stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in steamish thought he stood,
The Hisonde, with eyes of flame,
Came gibbering through the tetsubin wood,
And burbled as it came!

Glish-glash! Glish-glash! And through and through
His ceramic blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its brew,
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Drip?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O greenjous day! Calloo! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas steamy, and the kyusu cups
Did steep and steam in place:
All mimsy were the green tea sups,
And the tokkuri vase.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Darksnap-Vyper

'Twas flimshaw, and the photo-gloams
Did glint and glimmer in the adlabs,
All murky were the chroma-dromes,
And the photomotes outgrabe.

"Beware the Split-Grade Enlarger, son!
The lenses glare, the filters glare!
Beware the dodging-burn, and shun
The frumious Burn-Dodge glare!"

He took his chromasheen in hand:
Long time the max-shadow he sought—
So rested he by the wash-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in fixative he stood,
The Split-Grade Enlarger, with eyes of bleach,
Came whiffling from the developer-wood,
And burbled as it reached!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
His easel-blade went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, and with its ghostly hue,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Split-Grade glare?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas flimshaw, and the photo-gloams
Did glint and glimmer in the adlabs,
All murky were the chroma-dromes,
And the photomotes outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gleamgash Scrivel

‘Twas strolly, and the gribble-nibs
Did fizz and flimble in the wabe;
All flawy were the squibber-scribs,
And the kiridashi outgrabe.

“Beware the Scribe Line, scribbling son!
The words that slash, the thoughts that smutch!
Beware the Gleamgash, and shun
The frumious Ink-sputch!”

He took his vellum blade in hand:
Long time the lexic foe he sought—
So flazed he by the rillagram,
And blotted awhile in thought.

And as in whiffling thought he blotched,
The Scribe Line, with its glyphs of scorn,
Came scrittering from the plotch-grotched!
It paragraphed with scorn!

Snick-snack! He cleft the kernèd type,
His kiridashi slit the screed!
He left it dead, and with its hype
He went galumphing at full speed.

‘Twas strolly, and the gribble-nibs
Did fizz and flimble in the wabe;
All flawy were the squibber-scribs,
And the kiridashi outgrabe.
